title: How to Make Street Enchiladas

steps.headline: Cook the enchilada sauce, broth, and honey for 20 minutes.
steps.description: Pour the enchilada sauce, beef broth, and honey into a saucepan. Stir everything together with a wooden spoon. Bring the sauce to a simmer over low heat. Allow it to cook until it turns thick, about 20 minutes.

steps.headline: Heat the oil in a skillet over medium heat.
steps.description: Set a skillet on the stove. Pour enough oil into it to cover the bottom. Turn the heat up to medium, and allow the oil to get hot.

steps.headline: Dip a tortilla into the enchilada sauce.
steps.description: Drag the tortilla across the rim of the saucepan to remove any excess sauce. Make sure that you cover both sides of the tortilla. 4-inch (10.16-centimeter) con tortillas are recommended for this recipe.

steps.headline: Fry the tortilla on both sides.
steps.description: Set the tortilla down into the skillet. If you have enough space, you can set down a few more sauce-coated tortillas as well. Fry the tortilla for 15 to 30 seconds, flip it over with a spatula, then fry it for 15 to 30 seconds more. This will sear the sauce into the tortilla.

steps.headline: Fill the tortilla with your choice of shredded meat.
steps.description: Fill half of the tortilla with your choice of shredded meat, then fold the other half over--like a taco.

steps.headline: Continue making more enchiladas, then set them into a cast iron pan.
steps.description: Stand the enchiladas upright, with the folded part against the bottom of the pan. They will look a little like tacos. Set the enchiladas down side-by-side until the pan is filled.

steps.headline: Top it off with cheese, cilantro, and onion.
steps.description: Sprinkle the enchiladas with some crumbled cheese, chopped cilantro, and diced onion. If you have any leftover enchilada sauce, drizzle it on top.

steps.headline: Bake the enchiladas, if desired.
steps.description: This is not absolutely necessary, but it will help make the enchiladas crispier. Preheat your oven to 350°F (177°C), then bake the enchiladas in the cast-iron skillet for 8 to 10 minutes.

steps.headline: Serve the enchiladas immediately.
steps.description: For an extra burst of flavor, serve them with some sliced avocado and lime wedges.

steps.headline: Cook the dried chilies for 15 minutes.
steps.description: Place the dried chilies into a medium-sized saucepan and cover them with water. Bring the water to a boil, then reduce it to a simmer. Allow the chilies to cook for 15 minutes. You can also use guajillos or chile California. You can also use 8 ancho peppers instead.

steps.headline: Drain then blend the cooked chilies with the chicken broth.
steps.description: Pour the chili water through a strainer over a sink. Toss the cooked chilies into a blender. Add 1 cup (240 milliliters) of chicken broth. Cover the blender, then blend until the mixture is smooth. Save the remaining 2 cups (475 milliliters) of chicken broth for later.

steps.headline: Heat the olive oil in a pan.
steps.description: Place a pan on the stove. Pour 2 tablespoons (30 milliliters) of olive oil into it. Heat the oil over medium heat. You will be making your sauce in this pan, so make sure that it is big enough.

steps.headline: Add the sauce, chicken broth and spices, then cook it some more.
steps.description: Once the oil is hot, pour in the blended chili sauce. Add the rest of the chicken broth, along with the cumin, oregano, garlic powder, onion powder, pepper, and salt and give it a stir with a wooden spoon. Bring the mixture to a boil, then immediately reduce it to a simmer.

steps.headline: Prepare the thickener.
steps.description: Measure the masa harina into a small bowl. Pour in the water. Stir them together with a fork or mini whisk until the mixture turns smooth. If you can't find any masa harina, you can use flour instead.

steps.headline: Pour the thickener into the sauce, then continue cooking until the sauce thickens.
steps.description: Pour the masa harina and water mixture into the pan. Stir it in with a whisk until no streaks remain. Cover the pan with a lid. Allow the sauce to cook over low heat until it turns thick, about 20 minutes. This completes the homemade enchilada sauce. You are now ready to prepare the enchiladas themselves.

steps.headline: Heat an oiled skillet over medium heat.
steps.description: Pour enough oil into a large skillet to cover the bottom. Set the skillet down on the stove, and turn the heat up to medium. Wait for the oil to get hot.

steps.headline: Dip the tortilla into the sauce.
steps.description: Drag the tortilla, front and back, across the edge of the pan to get rid of any excess sauce. You will be frying these tortillas, so only dip as many as you can fit onto your pan.

steps.headline: Fry the dipped tortillas.
steps.description: Depending on the size of your skillet, you may be able to fit several tortillas—don't let them overlap, however! Fry the tortillas for 15 to 20 seconds. Flip them over with a spatula, then fry them for 15 to 20 seconds more. This will sear the sauce into the tortillas.

steps.headline: Fill the tortillas, then fold them over like a taco.
steps.description: Use a spoon to scoop some of the cooked, shredded beef or chicken into the center of each tortilla. Fold the tortillas over, like a taco, then set them down into a platter. Keep dipping and filling the tortillas until there are none left. Beef picadillo is beef is recommended for this, but you can use your own filling as well.

steps.headline: Garnish and serve the enchiladas.
steps.description: You can top them with your desired garnishes, or you can place the garnishes into separate bowls. Great choices include lettuce, onions, tomatoes, cheese, and sour cream. If you have any sauce left over, keep it on the side.

text: Making Simple Street Enchiladas Cook the enchilada sauce, broth, and honey for 20 minutes. Pour the enchilada sauce, beef broth, and honey into a saucepan. Stir everything together with a wooden spoon. Bring the sauce to a simmer over low heat. Allow it to cook until it turns thick, about 20 minutes. Heat the oil in a skillet over medium heat. Set a skillet on the stove. Pour enough oil into it to cover the bottom. Turn the heat up to medium, and allow the oil to get hot. Dip a tortilla into the enchilada sauce. Drag the tortilla across the rim of the saucepan to remove any excess sauce. Make sure that you cover both sides of the tortilla. 4-inch (10.16-centimeter) con tortillas are recommended for this recipe. Fry the tortilla on both sides. Set the tortilla down into the skillet. If you have enough space, you can set down a few more sauce-coated tortillas as well. Fry the tortilla for 15 to 30 seconds, flip it over with a spatula, then fry it for 15 to 30 seconds more. This will sear the sauce into the tortilla. Fill the tortilla with your choice of shredded meat. Fill half of the tortilla with your choice of shredded meat, then fold the other half over--like a taco. Continue making more enchiladas, then set them into a cast iron pan. Stand the enchiladas upright, with the folded part against the bottom of the pan. They will look a little like tacos. Set the enchiladas down side-by-side until the pan is filled. Top it off with cheese, cilantro, and onion. Sprinkle the enchiladas with some crumbled cheese, chopped cilantro, and diced onion. If you have any leftover enchilada sauce, drizzle it on top. Bake the enchiladas, if desired. This is not absolutely necessary, but it will help make the enchiladas crispier. Preheat your oven to 350°F (177°C), then bake the enchiladas in the cast-iron skillet for 8 to 10 minutes. Serve the enchiladas immediately. For an extra burst of flavor, serve them with some sliced avocado and lime wedges. Making Street Enchiladas from Scratch Cook the dried chilies for 15 minutes. Place the dried chilies into a medium-sized saucepan and cover them with water. Bring the water to a boil, then reduce it to a simmer. Allow the chilies to cook for 15 minutes. You can also use guajillos or chile California. You can also use 8 ancho peppers instead. Drain then blend the cooked chilies with the chicken broth. Pour the chili water through a strainer over a sink. Toss the cooked chilies into a blender. Add 1 cup (240 milliliters) of chicken broth. Cover the blender, then blend until the mixture is smooth. Save the remaining 2 cups (475 milliliters) of chicken broth for later. Heat the olive oil in a pan. Place a pan on the stove. Pour 2 tablespoons (30 milliliters) of olive oil into it. Heat the oil over medium heat. You will be making your sauce in this pan, so make sure that it is big enough. Add the sauce, chicken broth and spices, then cook it some more. Once the oil is hot, pour in the blended chili sauce. Add the rest of the chicken broth, along with the cumin, oregano, garlic powder, onion powder, pepper, and salt and give it a stir with a wooden spoon. Bring the mixture to a boil, then immediately reduce it to a simmer. Prepare the thickener. Measure the masa harina into a small bowl. Pour in the water. Stir them together with a fork or mini whisk until the mixture turns smooth. If you can't find any masa harina, you can use flour instead. Pour the thickener into the sauce, then continue cooking until the sauce thickens. Pour the masa harina and water mixture into the pan. Stir it in with a whisk until no streaks remain. Cover the pan with a lid. Allow the sauce to cook over low heat until it turns thick, about 20 minutes. This completes the homemade enchilada sauce. You are now ready to prepare the enchiladas themselves. Heat an oiled skillet over medium heat. Pour enough oil into a large skillet to cover the bottom. Set the skillet down on the stove, and turn the heat up to medium. Wait for the oil to get hot. Dip the tortilla into the sauce. Drag the tortilla, front and back, across the edge of the pan to get rid of any excess sauce. You will be frying these tortillas, so only dip as many as you can fit onto your pan. Fry the dipped tortillas. Depending on the size of your skillet, you may be able to fit several tortillas—don't let them overlap, however! Fry the tortillas for 15 to 20 seconds. Flip them over with a spatula, then fry them for 15 to 20 seconds more. This will sear the sauce into the tortillas. Fill the tortillas, then fold them over like a taco. Use a spoon to scoop some of the cooked, shredded beef or chicken into the center of each tortilla. Fold the tortillas over, like a taco, then set them down into a platter. Keep dipping and filling the tortillas until there are none left. Beef picadillo is beef is recommended for this, but you can use your own filling as well. Garnish and serve the enchiladas. You can top them with your desired garnishes, or you can place the garnishes into separate bowls. Great choices include lettuce, onions, tomatoes, cheese, and sour cream. If you have any sauce left over, keep it on the side.
sentences: Making Simple Street Enchiladas Cook the enchilada sauce, broth, and honey for 20 minutes.
Pour the enchilada sauce, beef broth, and honey into a saucepan.
Stir everything together with a wooden spoon.
Bring the sauce to a simmer over low heat.
Allow it to cook until it turns thick, about 20 minutes.
Heat the oil in a skillet over medium heat.
Set a skillet on the stove.
Pour enough oil into it to cover the bottom.
Turn the heat up to medium, and allow the oil to get hot.
Dip a tortilla into the enchilada sauce.
Drag the tortilla across the rim of the saucepan to remove any excess sauce.
Make sure that you cover both sides of the tortilla.
4-inch (10.16-centimeter) con tortillas are recommended for this recipe.
Fry the tortilla on both sides.
Set the tortilla down into the skillet.
If you have enough space, you can set down a few more sauce-coated tortillas as well.
Fry the tortilla for 15 to 30 seconds, flip it over with a spatula, then fry it for 15 to 30 seconds more.
This will sear the sauce into the tortilla.
Fill the tortilla with your choice of shredded meat.
Fill half of the tortilla with your choice of shredded meat, then fold the other half over--like a taco.
Continue making more enchiladas, then set them into a cast iron pan.
Stand the enchiladas upright, with the folded part against the bottom of the pan.
They will look a little like tacos.
Set the enchiladas down side-by-side until the pan is filled.
Top it off with cheese, cilantro, and onion.
Sprinkle the enchiladas with some crumbled cheese, chopped cilantro, and diced onion.
If you have any leftover enchilada sauce, drizzle it on top.
Bake the enchiladas, if desired.
This is not absolutely necessary, but it will help make the enchiladas crispier.
Preheat your oven to 350°F (177°C), then bake the enchiladas in the cast-iron skillet for 8 to 10 minutes.
Serve the enchiladas immediately.
For an extra burst of flavor, serve them with some sliced avocado and lime wedges.
Making Street Enchiladas from Scratch Cook the dried chilies for 15 minutes.
Place the dried chilies into a medium-sized saucepan and cover them with water.
Bring the water to a boil, then reduce it to a simmer.
Allow the chilies to cook for 15 minutes.
You can also use guajillos or chile California.
You can also use 8 ancho peppers instead.
Drain then blend the cooked chilies with the chicken broth.
Pour the chili water through a strainer over a sink.
Toss the cooked chilies into a blender.
Add 1 cup (240 milliliters) of chicken broth.
Cover the blender, then blend until the mixture is smooth.
Save the remaining 2 cups (475 milliliters) of chicken broth for later.
Heat the olive oil in a pan.
Place a pan on the stove.
Pour 2 tablespoons (30 milliliters) of olive oil into it.
Heat the oil over medium heat.
You will be making your sauce in this pan, so make sure that it is big enough.
Add the sauce, chicken broth and spices, then cook it some more.
Once the oil is hot, pour in the blended chili sauce.
Add the rest of the chicken broth, along with the cumin, oregano, garlic powder, onion powder, pepper, and salt and give it a stir with a wooden spoon.
Bring the mixture to a boil, then immediately reduce it to a simmer.
Prepare the thickener.
Measure the masa harina into a small bowl.
Pour in the water.
Stir them together with a fork or mini whisk until the mixture turns smooth.
If you can't find any masa harina, you can use flour instead.
Pour the thickener into the sauce, then continue cooking until the sauce thickens.
Pour the masa harina and water mixture into the pan.
Stir it in with a whisk until no streaks remain.
Cover the pan with a lid.
Allow the sauce to cook over low heat until it turns thick, about 20 minutes.
This completes the homemade enchilada sauce.
You are now ready to prepare the enchiladas themselves.
Heat an oiled skillet over medium heat.
Pour enough oil into a large skillet to cover the bottom.
Set the skillet down on the stove, and turn the heat up to medium.
Wait for the oil to get hot.
Dip the tortilla into the sauce.
Drag the tortilla, front and back, across the edge of the pan to get rid of any excess sauce.
You will be frying these tortillas, so only dip as many as you can fit onto your pan.
Fry the dipped tortillas.
Depending on the size of your skillet, you may be able to fit several tortillas—don't let them overlap, however!
Fry the tortillas for 15 to 20 seconds.
Flip them over with a spatula, then fry them for 15 to 20 seconds more.
This will sear the sauce into the tortillas.
Fill the tortillas, then fold them over like a taco.
Use a spoon to scoop some of the cooked, shredded beef or chicken into the center of each tortilla.
Fold the tortillas over, like a taco, then set them down into a platter.
Keep dipping and filling the tortillas until there are none left.
Beef picadillo is beef is recommended for this, but you can use your own filling as well.
Garnish and serve the enchiladas.
You can top them with your desired garnishes, or you can place the garnishes into separate bowls.
Great choices include lettuce, onions, tomatoes, cheese, and sour cream.
If you have any sauce left over, keep it on the side.
